title: Ticket #3336: Networking not fully started before HTCondor startup.
description:
It looks like on exec-7 (and possibly on the Debian 6 machine, see below), NetworkManager is forking into the background before it actually configures the network (see logs below). I don't know if this is because it's horribly broken (probable) or if there's something wrong with our switches, where they don't turn their ports on "fast enough" -- it takes three seconds for the link to come up, and another second for DHCP, but Condor starts two seconds after NetworkManager tries to bring the device up.

NTPd has a similar problem, but works around it; see below.

(I ran into this problem on the Debian 6 VM I installed for run-as-root testing, and added a 'sleep 5' to the condor initscript to work around it; I didn't do any more analysis.)

remarks:
2012-Nov-26 16:34:43 by tlmiller:
I spoke with Moate, and it's possible that this is a problem with our networking configuration. This would be more likely if the host in question were a VM, but it's possible for the problem to occur with physical hardware as well.

I've added him to the notify list so that he can report here, as well.

2014-Dec-09 16:19:26 by tlmiller:
Tom Downes writes: 

Todd / Condor Team:

I strongly suspect that this problem is a result of Debian's default value
of allow-hotplug in the /etc/network/interfaces file. I think that causes
the boot-time networking startup scripts to allow backgrounding of the dhcp
client. The right thing to do is "auto eth0" (or "auto lo eth0 eth#....").

Hard to prove a negative but it works empirically and seems to be what one
ought to expect given the networking script's interpretation of what
hotplug means.

I would not describe it as the most intuitive consequence of allowing
hotplugging but there you are.

See also #3506.
